results.content: Not enough exercises to go along with the information. Mostly straight lecture, without helpful charts, examples, or other graphics.
results.content_html: Not enough exercises to go along with the information. Mostly straight lecture, without helpful charts, examples, or other graphics.

results.content: At first I thought in my honest and humble opinion this course was not worth the time/money spent going through.  However as the course progresses it becomes some what entertaining.  Some advice though.  Please, get to the point sooner and reduce some of the waffle.  Not everyone on this course lives in America and/or can related to some of the off the wall discussions  (For example; American football and quarterbacks).  In the CSS section I think it would have been better to show some examples of different styles and what effect specificity may have on the styles. It can be soooo much better, but it is not as bad I had originally thought.  Martin Kenny is obviously very knowledgeable.

results.content: I got through roughly 25% (got to lecture 12 of 50) of the class and learned very little.  Too much time spent rambling about one example after another.  Whole Foods, to the Library to the Military.  So far, and this is when I quit after several hours (wanted to give it a chance) and can say everything covered could have been done in 5-10 minutes.  The person clearly just rambled.  Had a script been prepared and followed, it might have been a good course.  If you want to learn something and spend your time wisely, stay away from this one!

results.content:
Very clear and descriptive, but too much descriptive and detailed for those who already have experience with HTML, CSS & JS.
Recommended for absolute beginners.

results.content: Unfortunately, this course takes you from being a complete beginner and leaves you at being a complete beginner. The content is not interactive and the lectures are long winded. Sections are missing from the lectures and the course is disjointed. I hope the instructor is able to fix these issues.

Sections are missing from the lectures and the course is disjointed. I hope the instructor is able to fix these issues.

results.content: over all i really enjoy this Kenny teaching style.  at times (less then a handful) he can get a bit long winded with his seemingly abstract and obscure analogies but in the end you understand his approach and you understand the material.... this is why we are all here right?  to understand, to learn.  and this coding is a daunting journey to take for a newbie. i just wish he had more courses. especially higher level courses. if you have no experience in programming i HIGHLY recommend a martin kenny course FIRST.

results.content: I am really hanging out for a good, comprehensive course in Javascript that takes a novice to a working mastery of the code.  Alas, this course talks a lot about the value of Javascript and offers just enough snippets of solid information to keep me going on.  But It doesn't meet my needs.  Does Udemy have such a course?  Other web instructors offer practical applications using JS, but do not cover the fundamentals so I as a novice in the language, still wrestle with concepts and adaptations of scripts to do what I want with them.
results.content_html: I am really hanging out for a good, comprehensive course in Javascript that takes a novice to a working mastery of the code. Alas, this course talks a lot about the value of Javascript and offers just enough snippets of solid information to keep me going on. But It doesn't meet my needs. Does Udemy have such a course? Other web instructors offer practical applications using JS, but do not cover the fundamentals so I as a novice in the language, still wrestle with concepts and adaptations of scripts to do what I want with them.

results.content:
There's way too much talking here. I kept skipping ahead and hearing a bunch of analogies instead of the stuff I wanted to learn. Maybe it gets better once you get past all the junk, but I skipped ahead an hour into the "diving in" section and there's still no "diving in."

It's so long winded that I just decided to buy another course instead.

results.content: This is not actually a beginner to Javascript but a beginner to web developer. Only the 1/3 of course is dedicated to JS while the 2/3 are very basic, html and css.

response.content: Hey George, thank you for writing your comments here. I agree that some students come to the course with varying levels of skill and background making the meaning of "beginner" relative. Nonetheless, your feedback is much appreciated and goes towards creating a better student experience.

results.content:
I bought this course hoping to gain a bit more clarity on the concept of closures and anonymous functions, which is more of an intermediate topic but are used by pretty much every javascript developer out there.  What this course is is nothing but lectures without a lot of 'doing' and implementing the concepts discussed.


Perhaps it is just a style preference but I felt like this course didn't use enough interactive examples and the lectures felt like the author was talking at me rather than simply moving from one concept to another.  In fact, the lectures were so long, I could feel myself getting "lost in my own thoughts" rather than paying attention.  

For example, in the 'baby steps' section (which is over an hour long), Martin tries to explain what happens to HTTP requests and responses between the server and browser.  But it felt like what he was trying to explain could have been done more succinctly and the examples he used (he kept comparing it to borrowing books from the library) didn't bring anymore clarity to the topic.  What's more is he uses very few visual props on the video to move things along.  So, what you get is basically a tutorial that may as well be an audio recording.

I thought that maybe this was just an anomaly because it is in the introduction but section 2 and the proceeding sections all follow the same format.  Long winded, with no interaction.  Just a lecture with very few actual examples that could make me feel engaged with the lessons.

So, once again, this may be a learning style conflict.  If your learning style is to actually implement what you are learning in a IDE or text editor, with examples that the author gives, then this class is not for you.  You will be disappointed with the delivery.
results.content_html:
I bought this course hoping to gain a bit more clarity on the concept of closures and anonymous functions, which is more of an intermediate topic but are used by pretty much every javascript developer out there. What this course is is nothing but lectures without a lot of 'doing' and implementing the concepts discussed.

Perhaps it is just a style preference but I felt like this course didn't use enough interactive examples and the lectures felt like the author was talking at me rather than simply moving from one concept to another. In fact, the lectures were so long, I could feel myself getting "lost in my own thoughts" rather than paying attention.

For example, in the 'baby steps' section (which is over an hour long), Martin tries to explain what happens to HTTP requests and responses between the server and browser. But it felt like what he was trying to explain could have been done more succinctly and the examples he used (he kept comparing it to borrowing books from the library) didn't bring anymore clarity to the topic. What's more is he uses very few visual props on the video to move things along. So, what you get is basically a tutorial that may as well be an audio recording.

I thought that maybe this was just an anomaly because it is in the introduction but section 2 and the proceeding sections all follow the same format. Long winded, with no interaction. Just a lecture with very few actual examples that could make me feel engaged with the lessons.

So, once again, this may be a learning style conflict. If your learning style is to actually implement what you are learning in a IDE or text editor, with examples that the author gives, then this class is not for you. You will be disappointed with the delivery.
